awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Key to the Cabinets: Building and Sustaining a Research Database for a Global Biodiversity Hotspot
awd_abstract_narration:
The southeastern USA is botanically rich, with areas of high global biodiversity in both the Appalachians and the coastal plain.  Millions of plant specimens have been collected from this region over the past four centuries, and these specimens and the information they contain currently reside in museums, or herbaria, at universities across the area.  Scientists study these specimens intently; however, it is difficult to retrieve information at broad geographic and taxonomic scales without pipelines to move the information electronically from the specimen to an accessible pool of data.  SERNEC, or the SouthEast Regional Network of Expertise and Collections, is a large regional network of botanical experts and collections that has, through an NSF-sponsored research coordination network (RCN) project, developed critical skills in biodiversity informatics.  The current project will allow the SERNEC group to make data available for over 3 million specimens using the latest photography and information capture tools and to engage citizen scientists and students to assist in transcribing and georeferencing this large dataset.  The research generated through this project can help regional planners, land managers and communities to manage their natural resources in our ever-changing environment.  

The interaction of scientists, citizen scientists, and students will provide a synergy to build a research tool of an unparalleled scale and scope.  The ultimate goal of this project is to develop an imaged and databased set of over 3 million specimens from over 100 herbaria in one of the most floristically diverse regions in North America and a global hotspot of plant diversity. This will represent a valuable data source for research on the response of vegetation to climate change, human development, and rapid migrations of introduced species. This region has been a biodiversity hotspot for 100 million years and this project should encourage research on changes over time to develop better predictive models as areas of biodiversity change. By partnering with Symbiota, Notes from Nature, GEOLocate, Adler Planetarium, iPlant/TACC, and Specify, the project will develop ways to best integrate various efforts for data accessibility. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program, and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

por.por_cntn:
During this project ten different herbaria in South Carolina worked together over five years to make digital images of the plant specimens housed in their collections. This was part of a broader effort to collect images and data from collections scattered all over the Southeastern United States. Led by Clemson University (CLEMS) and the University of South Carolina (USCH), digital images were captured and published from Newberry College (NBYC), the University of South Carolina Upstate (USCS), Furman University (FUGR), Francis Marion University (FMUH), Converse College (CONV), Winthrop University (WINU), the University of South Carolina at Salkehatchie (SALK) and the Silver Bluff Audubon Center and Sanctuary (SBAC). Over 70 contributors -- including Faculty, staff, students and volunteers -- worked together to process and publish over 200,000 plant images that are available to the public through SERNEC (http://sernecportal.org/portal/collections/index.php).

Funding for the project aimed to digitize approximately 90% (about 228,000 records) of all the specimens collected from the Southeastern (SE) United States that are housed in herbaria in South Carolina. To date we have achieved approximately 88% of our original target and work continues at several of the herbaria involved, supported by volunteer work (contributed by Faculty, staff, students and the public) and internal funding.

The project has been a great benefit to the stakeholders involved. The intellectual merits of the project emphasize the potential of this new and extensive data to enhance and expand research in a number of disciplines related to traditional botanical studies but also supporting work in climate studies, environmental and ecological studies, land management and almost any other field that can utilize “big data” studies. This project helps preserve the information found in large and small collections in South Carolina and particularly helps illuminate and share the valuable smaller collections too often ignored in large-scale research.

The broader merits of this project center on: 1) the greater availability of more data to a larger audience, and 2) connecting and involving new communities with scientific methods and institutions. The wealth of new information now available means that regional, national and international researchers can apply this data to agricultural, ecological and environmental studies and also incorporate it into natural resource management plans. For the individual herbaria involved, it means that the collections have achieved a higher profile within their institutions. As a direct result of the project, several of the collaborating herbaria are now able to offer information about their collections to an online audience for the first time. The impact on the students employed in the project is particularly significant. The project has given a gender-balanced cohort of students representing diverse ethnic backgrounds and academic interests a meaningful introduction to the process of scientific research and to botanical and environmental studies. Volunteers from the ‘general’ public have also experienced the methods and importance of scientific research in the herbaria involved.

Overall, the five year project has helped make data housed in South Carolina herbaria accessible to a global scientific community while at the same time energizing SC herbaria and helping them build a greater sense of community and collective enterprise.
